[[File:Nobel medal dsc06171.png|right|200px|thumb|Front side (obverse) of the Nobel Prize Medal for Physics presented to [[Edward Victor Appleton]] in 1947]] The [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] ({{lang-sv|Nobelpriset i fysik}}) is awarded annually by the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] to scientists in the various fields of [[physics]]. It is one of the five [[Nobel Prize]]s established by the 1895 [[Will (law)|will]] of [[Alfred Nobel]] (who died in 1896), awarded for outstanding contributions in physics.{{cite web |title=Alfred Nobel â The Man Behind the Nobel Prize |publisher=Nobel Foundation |url=http://nobelprize.org/alfred_nobel/ |accessdate=2008-10-29}} As dictated by Nobel's will, the award is administered by the [[Nobel Foundation]] and awarded by a committee that consists of five members elected by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences.{{cite web |title=The Nobel Prize Awarders |publisher=Nobel Foundation |url=http://nobelprize.org/prize_awarders/ |accessdate=2008-10-29}} The first Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded in 1901 to [[Wilhelm Conrad RÃ¶ntgen]], of [[Germany]]. Each recipient receives a medal, a diploma and a monetary award prize that has varied throughout the years.{{cite web |title=The Nobel Prize |publisher=Nobel Foundation |url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/ |accessdate=2008-10-29}} In 1901, RÃ¶ntgen received 150,782 [[Swedish krona|SEK]], which is equal to 7,731,004 SEK in December 2007. In 2008, the prize was awarded to [[Makoto Kobayashi (physicist)|Makoto Kobayashi]], [[Toshihide Maskawa]] and [[Yoichiro Nambu]] who shared the prize amount of 10,000,000 SEK (slightly more than [[Euro|â¬]]1 million, or [[United States dollar|US$]]1.4 million).{{cite web |title=The Nobel Prize Amounts |publisher=Nobel Foundation |url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/amounts.html |accessdate=2008-10-29 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080731233358/http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/amounts.html |archivedate=2008-07-31}} The award is presented in [[Stockholm]] at an annual ceremony on December 10, the anniversary of Nobel's death.{{cite web |title=The Nobel Prize Award Ceremonies |publisher=Nobel Foundation |url=http://nobelprize.org/award_ceremonies/ |accessdate=2008-10-29 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080822184717/http://nobelprize.org/award_ceremonies/ |archivedate=2008-08-22}} [[John Bardeen]] is the only laureate to win the prize twiceâin 1956 and 1972. One other has also won Nobel Prizes in other subjects: [[Marie Curie]] (physics in 1903, chemistry in 1911). [[William Lawrence Bragg]] is the youngest ever Nobel Laureate; he won the prize in 1915 at the age of 25.{{cite web |title=Nobel Laureates Facts |publisher=Nobel Foundation |url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/nobelprize_facts.html |accessdate=2008-10-29}} Two women have won the prize: Marie Curie and [[Maria Goeppert-Mayer]] (1963), which is the least of any of the original five Nobel Prizes.{{cite web |title=Women Nobel Laureates |publisher=Nobel Foundation |url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/lists/women.html |accessdate=2008-10-29}} As of 2011, the prize has been awarded to 191 individuals.
